Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The effect of temperature and low oxygen on muscle performance, oxygen uptake and delivery in fish exposed to disparate thermal environments
Award.AbstractNarration:
Temperature plays an important role in the biology of animals, particularly for those that sustain high levels of locomotor activity, as both muscle performance and blood-oxygen binding properties are directly affected. For most vertebrates, in which body temperature is similar to that of the surrounding environment, a change in ambient temperature will have profound effects on physiology. Marine pelagic fishes live in a thermally-stable environment marked by significant variation in temperature only with depth and latitude. While many fish remain within a narrow temperature range some are known to migrate across wide latitudinal ranges or dive into deeper, colder water. Of those species that routinely dive, few are capable of sustaining long periods of time within the cold, deep ocean. The swordfish is one of relatively few active fish species capable of diving for extended periods of time in the deep, cold, and oxygen depleted waters and then rapidly returning to the warm surface waters. The ability to withstand and routinely transition between disparate environmental regimes makes the swordfish an ideal candidate for studies of the effects of temperature and hypoxia on vertebrate muscle function and oxygen transport.

This study will assess the effects of temperature and hypoxia tolerance on muscle performance, cardiorespiratory function, and gene expression in fishes with different levels of tolerance for these extreme ambient conditions. This study builds upon previous NSF-funded research on muscle function and will increase our understanding of how selective pressures have lead to adaptations for life on the edge. This project will involve numerous students (high school, undergraduate, and graduate level) in hands-on field and laboratory research. The findings from this work will be communicated to the general public (including local fishermen and K-12) via seminars, presentations and internet portals. The results from this work will also be communicated in accessible formats to scientific, management, and public communities with the intent to foster greater awareness of scientific inquiry, discovery and progress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-sponsored study tested hypotheses on how temperature affects muscle function and cardiovascular performance in a group of deep-diving marine fish species.  This collaborative project also elucidated the morphological and circulatory specializations that allow certain fishes to maintain muscle function when exposed to rapid changes in ambient temperature and dissolved oxygen. This NSF study brought together several research groups with disparate fields of expertise in order to increase our understanding of the physiological adaptations in marine species that are known for their marked tolerance to extreme changes in environmental temperatures at depth (i.e., swordfish and bigeye thresher sharks).  In addition, this NSF-sponsored work offered a multitude of high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students with the unprecedented opportunity to work (on land and at sea) on a cutting-edge scientific research project .  

This collaborative project coupled innovative field studies on wild, free-swimming fish with laboratory investigations that spanned from work on live-isolated muscle preparations to anatomical and histological investigations that are associated with oxygen delivery and thermal balance.  The overall goal of this study was to examine and better understand how marine organisms with a high aerobic demand can maintain physiological function (from a cellular to whole-organismal level) during rapid and large movements between environments with large differences in ambient temperature and oxygen levels . 

Our findings revealed that swordfish possess circulatory modifications that allow the body (i.e., red aerobic swimming muscles) to maintain a temperature that is elevated relative to the water at depth, a trait only shared by a few other select marine fish groups (i.e., tunas and lamnid sharks).  These data allowed us to build numerical models that predict how swordfish body temperature may change during their foraging sojourns into colder water. Our work also identified how the contractile kinetics and muscle performance of swordfish are different from those of the bigeye thresher shark, a species that experiences similar dive patterns to swordfish but is not capable of an elevated body temperature. Specially, we documented how swordfish swimming muscle performance is optimized over a relatively small thermal range compared to bigeye thresher sharks, which can maintain muscle function, albeit slowly, in cold water. The products of this work have not only given us a better understanding of the swimming performance and thermal tolerances of a fish species with the capacity to tolerate large changes in temperature and dissolved oxygen but have also used new physiological information to provide the basis for new habitat utilization and niche partitioning models.  Our laboratory and field findings reported in this study help explain the expansive range exhibited by swordfish and its heightened capacity to remain at depth for hours at a time and maintain surface-like swimming performance.  The ability to exploit extreme environments and capitalize on the rich food resources found at depth provides swordfish and other warm-bodied predators an advantage over their cold and slow-moving prey. 

Our findings from this project on the physiological adaptations that allow for an expanded dive capacity in swordfish extend beyond the purely academic questions answered in this work and have offered a basis for increasing the development of new fishing gear selectivity and reducing global bycatch in a vast commercial fishery that extends into all of the ocean basins.  Sculpting fishing gears based on movements patterns and physiological performance can be strategically used to design fishing gears that minimize spatial overlap with sensitive and protected species.
